full_text.full_text:
(Ex) Naïve Bayes Classifier (2/2)
▪ First, we obtain P(No) = 0.7 and P(Yes) = 0.3
▪ Next, we compute P(No|x) and P(Yes|x) as follows:
– x = (Home Owner = No, Marital Status = Married, Annual Income = 120K)
–
𝑃 No 𝐱 ∝ 𝑃 No ∙ 𝑃 Home Owner = No No
∙ 𝑃 Marital Status = Married No
∙ 𝑃 Annual Income = 120K No
= 0.7 ∙ 4/7 ∙ 4/7 ∙ 0.072 = 0.7 ∙ 0.0024 = 0.0016
will be described soon
–
𝑃 Yes 𝐱 ∝ 𝑃 Yes ∙ 𝑃 Home Owner = No Yes
∙ 𝑃 Marital Status = Married Yes
∙ 𝑃 Annual Income = 120K Yes
= 0.3 ∙ 1 ∙ 0 ∙ 10−9 = 0
▪ Since P(No|x) > P(Yes|x), we classify x as No
28

text.text:
▪ First, we obtain P(No) = 0.7 and P(Yes) = 0.3
▪ Next, we compute P(No|x) and P(Yes|x) as follows:

– x = (Home Owner = No, Marital Status = Married, Annual Income = 120K)
–
𝑃 No 𝐱 ∝ 𝑃 No ∙ 𝑃 Home Owner = No No
∙ 𝑃 Marital Status = Married No
∙ 𝑃 Annual Income = 120K No
= 0.7 ∙ 4/7 ∙ 4/7 ∙ 0.072 = 0.7 ∙ 0.0024 = 0.0016

–
𝑃 Yes 𝐱 ∝ 𝑃 Yes ∙ 𝑃 Home Owner = No Yes
∙ 𝑃 Marital Status = Married Yes
∙ 𝑃 Annual Income = 120K Yes
= 0.3 ∙ 1 ∙ 0 ∙ 10−9 = 0
▪ Since P(No|x) > P(Yes|x), we classify x as No
